array.string: Anterior corticospinal tract

Small bundle of descending axons connecting the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord. The tract is located in close proximity to the anterior median fissure and is not present below the thoracic region of the spinal cord. Unlike axons of the lateral corticospinal tract, axons within the anterior corticospinal tract do not cross over in the medulla, but descend on the ipsilateral side of the spinal cord until close to the region of synapse and then the axons cross to the contralateral side. Neurons within the cerebral cortex often project bilaterally within the anterior cortical spinal tract to synapse with neurons within the anterior horn of gray matter responsible for innervating axial muscles.
Anterior spinothalamic tract

Also referred to as the ventral spinothalamic system, this spinal tract is responsible for carrying crude touch and firm pressure information from the periphery. The tract consists of axons from second order neurons from the contralateral side of the spinal cord. The axons within the tract ascend the spinal cord and synapse with third order neurons within the thalamus (VPL) and reticular formation.
Anterior white commissure
Thin zone of white mater located dorsal to the ventral median fissure. Consists of nerve fibers crossing over to the contralateral side of the spinal cord.
Anterolateral sulcus
Structural landmark on the spinal cord denoting the location in which the ventral rootlets exit the spinal cord.
Cauda equina
The large bundle of dorsal and ventral nerve roots that continue within the vertebral canal below the termination of the spinal cord within the lumbar cistern.

A functional subdivision of the nervous system that functions largely outside of conscious control and acts to control visceral functions. The two subdivisions within the autonomic nervous system are the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems, which act as antagonistic to each other. Preganglionic cell bodies of the sympathetic nervous system reside within the intermediolateral cell column. Some of the preganglionic cell bodies of the parasympathetic nervous system reside in the sacral parasympathetic nuclei (S2-4).

A functional subdivision of the nervous system that functions largely outside of conscious control and acts to control visceral functions. The two subdivisions within the autonomic nervous system are the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems, which act as antagonistic to each other. Preganglionic cell bodies of the sympathetic nervous system reside within the intermediolateral cell column. Some of the preganglionic cell bodies of the parasympathetic nervous system reside in the sacral parasympathetic nuclei (S2-4).
Cervical enlargement
Enlarged segment of the spinal cord usually spanning from the fifth cervical level to the first thoracic level. The cervical enlargement is involved with innervation of the upper extremities.
Enlarged segment of the spinal cord usually spanning from the fifth cervical level to the first thoracic level. The cervical enlargement is involved with innervation of the upper extremities.
Clarke’s nucleus (nucleus dorsalis)

Rounded collection of interneurons on the medial surface of the posterior horn base between the T1-L3 spinal levels. Main function is as a relay nucleus for information to the cerebellum via the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, such as proprioception.
Conus medullaris Conus medullaris
The termination of the spinal cord, which traditionally is located in the adult between vertebral levels L1-L2.
The termination of the spinal cord, which traditionally is located in the adult between vertebral levels L1-L2.
The termination of the spinal cord, which traditionally is located in the adult between vertebral levels L1-L2.
Dermatome
A strip of skin that is innervated by a single spinal nerve. C1 is the only spinal nerve without a dermatome.
A strip of skin that is innervated by a single spinal nerve. C1 is the only spinal nerve without a dermatome.
Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscus System

Ascending tract responsible for convey fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception from the periphery. The dorsal column of white matter inferior to T6 is organized into one group called the fasciculus gracilis. Superior to T6 the dorsal column is divided into the fasciculus gracilis (medially) and the fasciculus cuneatus (laterally). All first order sensory axons responsible for relaying fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception at T6 and below enter the spinal cord and ascend within the fasciculus gracilis. All first order sensory axons responsible for relaying fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception above T6 enter the spinal cord and ascend within the fasciculus cuneatus. Axons within each fasciculus ascend on the ipsilateral side of the spinal cord until reaching their respective nucleus within the caudal medulla. The axons of the second order neurons cross to the contralateral side of the brainstem within a group of axons called the medial lemniscus, which synapse with third order neurons within the thalamus.
Dorsal horn of gray matter

This column of gray matter is formed mainly by interneurons, afferent projection nuclei, and central neuroglia. Sensory information from the periphery is relayed from the afferent nuclei in the dorsal root ganglia to synapse with the afferent nuclei within the dorsal gray horn. Two prominent parts of the dorsal horn of gray mater are the substantia gelatinosa and the body of the dorsal horn. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological alar plates.

This column of gray matter is formed mainly by interneurons, afferent projection nuclei, and central neuroglia. Sensory information from the periphery is relayed from the afferent nuclei in the dorsal root ganglia to synapse with the afferent nuclei within the dorsal gray horn. Two prominent parts of the dorsal horn of gray mater are the substantia gelatinosa and the body of the dorsal horn. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological alar plates.

This column of gray matter is formed mainly by interneurons, afferent projection nuclei, and central neuroglia. Sensory information from the periphery is relayed from the afferent nuclei in the dorsal root ganglia to synapse with the afferent nuclei within the dorsal gray horn. Two prominent parts of the dorsal horn of gray mater are the substantia gelatinosa and the body of the dorsal horn. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological alar plates.

This column of gray matter is formed mainly by interneurons, afferent projection nuclei, and central neuroglia. Sensory information from the periphery is relayed from the afferent nuclei in the dorsal root ganglia to synapse with the afferent nuclei within the dorsal gray horn. Two prominent parts of the dorsal horn of gray mater are the substantia gelatinosa and the body of the dorsal horn. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological alar plates.
Dorsal intermediate sulcus
Longitudinal groove located in only the cervical and upper thoracic levels of the spinal cord. This denotes the separation of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus.
Dorsal median sulcus
Shallow narrow groove extending to the gray mater surrounding the central canal.
Dorsal roots of spinal nerves
Collection of central axon processes from pseudounipolar neurons within the dorsal root ganglion carrying sensory information. Continues as the dorsal rootlets into the spinal cord.
Collection of central axon processes from pseudounipolar neurons within the dorsal root ganglion carrying sensory information. Continues as the dorsal rootlets into the spinal cord.
Collection of central axon processes from pseudounipolar neurons within the dorsal root ganglion carrying sensory information. Continues as the dorsal rootlets into the spinal cord.
Dorsal root ganglion

Aggregation of pseudounipolar neurons situated within the dorsal roots. These are the cell bodies of the primary sensory neurons whose central processes pass into the spinal cord and peripheral processes travel through the spinal nerve. These pseudounipolar neurons are derived from neural crest cells. Satellite neuroglial cells are also present within the ganglion.

Aggregation of pseudounipolar neurons situated within the dorsal roots. These are the cell bodies of the primary sensory neurons whose central processes pass into the spinal cord and peripheral processes travel through the spinal nerve. These pseudounipolar neurons are derived from neural crest cells. Satellite neuroglial cells are also present within the ganglion.

Aggregation of pseudounipolar neurons situated within the dorsal roots. These are the cell bodies of the primary sensory neurons whose central processes pass into the spinal cord and peripheral processes travel through the spinal nerve. These pseudounipolar neurons are derived from neural crest cells. Satellite neuroglial cells are also present within the ganglion.

Aggregation of pseudounipolar neurons situated within the dorsal roots. These are the cell bodies of the primary sensory neurons whose central processes pass into the spinal cord and peripheral processes travel through the spinal nerve. These pseudounipolar neurons are derived from neural crest cells. Satellite neuroglial cells are also present within the ganglion.
Dorsal rootlets
Continuation of the nerve cell processes from the dorsal root. The dorsal rootlets enter the spinal cord at the posterolateral sulcus.
Dorsal spinocerebellar tract

Ascending tract responsible for conveying proprioceptive information from skeletal muscles and joints to the cerebellum. Axons relaying this sensory information synapse with Clarke’s nucleus. Axons from Clarke’s nucleus project to a portion of the lateral funiculus, which is the organized dorsal spinocerebellar tract. These axons enter the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminate within the ipsilateral side of the cerebellum, thus no part of this tract crosses to the contralateral side. Clarke’s nucleus does not extend below the L3 spinal cord level, and thus neither does the dorsal spinocerebellar tract.
Fasciculus cuneatus

Rostral to T6 the dorsal column of spinal cord white matter is divided by the posterior intermediate septum into the fasciculus cuneatus and gracilis. Consist of the first order axons for the medial lemniscus system rostral to T6.
Fasciculus gracilis

Caudal to T6 each dorsal column of spinal cord white matter consists of the undivided fasciculus gracilis. This fiber tract consists of large central processes of neuron cell bodies within dorsal root ganglia carrying information from various mechanoreceptors. Consist of the first order axons for the medial lemniscus system caudal to T6.
Fasciculus propius

Collection of nerve fibers located within the white matter of the spinal cord on the border of the gray matter. These nerve fibers within this tract can be ascending, descending, crossed or uncrossed in interconnecting various spinal cord levels.
Filum terminale

A long fibrous thread formed distal to the conus medullaris by the continuation of pia mater. The filum terminale continues inferiorly to attach to the coccyx, representing the original location of the developing spinal cord

A long fibrous thread formed distal to the conus medullaris by the continuation of pia mater. The filum terminale continues inferiorly to attach to the coccyx, representing the original location of the developing spinal cord

A long fibrous thread formed distal to the conus medullaris by the continuation of pia mater. The filum terminale continues inferiorly to attach to the coccyx, representing the original location of the developing spinal cord
Flaccid paralysis

Type of paralysis caused by lesion of lower motor neurons. The muscles supplied by the damaged lower motor neurons become limp and unable to contract. Reflex contractions are no longer attainable and the muscle will begin to atrophy.
Funiculus
Common division of the spinal cord white matter. Divided into ventral, dorsal and lateral funiculi.
Fusimotor neurons
Gamma motor neurons scattered within groups of alpha motor neurons. These motor neurons are responsible for innervating muscle spindles.
Intermediolateral cell column

Column of preganglionic sympathetic neurons located between T1-L2. On the gross spinal cord this column of cells is evident as the lateral horn of gray matter. Axons of these neurons exit the spinal cord via the ventral roots.
Lateral corticospinal tract

Descending motor tract consisting of axons from the contralateral motor cortex (upper motor neurons). These fibers crossed within the caudal medulla at the pyramidal decussation to descend the remainder of the spinal cord on the contralateral side. Axons within this tract will synapse with neurons in the spinal cord along its length (lower motor neurons). The lower motor neurons leave the spinal cord to innervate skeletal muscle allowing for voluntary movement.
Lateral spinothalamic tract

Together with the anterior spinothalamic tract, collectively referred to as the anterolateral system. Axons within the lateral spinothalamic tract convey pain and temperature sensation from the contralateral side of the body. The axons occupying the tract ascend to synapse with neurons within the thalamus as well as axons within reticular formation.
Lissauer’s tract

Located between the substantia gelatinosa and the surface of the spinal cord. Consists of centrally projecting axons from neurons within the dorsal root ganglion specifically relaying pain and temperature information. The axons within this tract ascend 1-2 spinal segments before synapsing with second-order neurons within the substantia gelatinosa.
Lower motor neuron
Alpha motor neurons located within the ventral horn of gray matter responsible for innervating skeletal muscles.
Lumbar cistern

Enlarged space between the termination of the spinal cord (L1-2) and the inferior extent of the arachnoid and dura mater (S2). Occupants within the space include: ventral and dorsal roots (cauda equina), filum terminale and cerebrospinal fluid.

Enlarged space between the termination of the spinal cord (L1-2) and the inferior extent of the arachnoid and dura mater (S2). Occupants within the space include: ventral and dorsal roots (cauda equina), filum terminale and cerebrospinal fluid.
Lumbar enlargement

Enlarged segment of the spinal cord usually spanning from the second lumbar level to the third sacral level. The lumbar (or lumbosacral) enlargement is involved with innervation of the lower extremities.

Enlarged segment of the spinal cord usually spanning from the second lumbar level to the third sacral level. The lumbar (or lumbosacral) enlargement is involved with innervation of the lower extremities.
Onuf’s nucleus
Located in the lateral portion of the ventral horn of gray matter between S1-3 spinal levels. Responsible for innervating sphincter and erectile musculature.
Phrenic nucleus

Motor neurons located in the medial aspect of the ventral horn of gray matter between spinal levels C3-5. The axons emerge from these neurons to form the phrenic nerve, responsible for innervation of the diaphragm.
Posterolateral sulcus
Shallow longitudinal groove found at the posterolateral surface of the spinal. This groove denotes the entrance of dorsal rootlets into the spinal cord.
Reticulospinal tract

Descending motor tract consisting of axons from reticular formation neurons. The reticulospinal tract is made up of two smaller tracts: the medial (pontine) reticulospinal tract and the lateral (medullary) reticulospinal tract. This tract has many functions including: integration of information to aid in automatic movements of posture and locomotion, facilitates and inhibits voluntary movement and modulates pain impulses.
Rubrospinal tract

Descending motor tract consisting of axons from neurons located within the red nucleus. The descending axons cross immediately upon exiting the red nucleus to occupy the contralateral brainstem and thus spinal cord. This tract functions to provide strong output to limbs and allowing for accurate hand shape and placement (particularly in primates).
Sacral parasympathetic nucleus

Column of preganglionic parasympathetic neurons located between S2-4. This column of cells does not form a distinct lateral horn of gray matter, though in a similar location as the intermediolateral cell column. Axons of these neurons exit the spinal cord via the ventral roots. Project to and synapse with postganglionic neurons for the bladder, bowel and genitals.
Somatotopic
Common organization of both motor and sensory pathways in which particular portions of the body are represented in particular regions of a pathway or nucleus.
Spastic paralysis

Type of paralysis caused by lesion of upper motor neurons. The muscles supplied by the damaged upper motor neurons present with hyperactive reflexes, are hypertonic and present with paralysis and/or weakness specifically in regards to fine voluntary movements.
Spinal accessory nucleus
Collection of motor neurons spanning from the caudal medulla to the C5 spinal level. The axons emerge from these neurons to form the rootlets of the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).
Spinal nerve

Generally a mixed nerve formed by the combination of the ventral and dorsal roots. There are thirty-one pairs of spinal nerves. These nerves are responsible for carrying motor, sensory and autonomic fibers.

Generally a mixed nerve formed by the combination of the ventral and dorsal roots. There are thirty-one pairs of spinal nerves. These nerves are responsible for carrying motor, sensory and autonomic fibers.
Substantia gelatinosa

Distinctive region of gray matter capping the dorsal horn of gray matter. Primary, or first order neurons within the dorsal root ganglia involved in the spinothalamic tract synapse with the neurons located within this space.
Upper motor neuron
Neurons whose cell bodies begin in the cerebral cortex, and whose axons descend through the spinal cord to synapse on lower motor neurons.
Ventral horn of gray matter

This column of gray matter consists predominately of a large aggregation of basophilic alpha motor neuron cell bodies, dendrites, axons and central neuroglia. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological basal plates. Axons of neurons located within the ventral horn of gray matter grow out of the spinal cord and form the majority of the ventral root of spinal nerves.

This column of gray matter consists predominately of a large aggregation of basophilic alpha motor neuron cell bodies, dendrites, axons and central neuroglia. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological basal plates. Axons of neurons located within the ventral horn of gray matter grow out of the spinal cord and form the majority of the ventral root of spinal nerves.

This column of gray matter consists predominately of a large aggregation of basophilic alpha motor neuron cell bodies, dendrites, axons and central neuroglia. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological basal plates. Axons of neurons located within the ventral horn of gray matter grow out of the spinal cord and form the majority of the ventral root of spinal nerves.

This column of gray matter consists predominately of a large aggregation of basophilic alpha motor neuron cell bodies, dendrites, axons and central neuroglia. This section of the spinal cord in the adult is derived from the embryological basal plates. Axons of neurons located within the ventral horn of gray matter grow out of the spinal cord and form the majority of the ventral root of spinal nerves.
Ventral median fissure
A deep longitudinal groove that extends almost to the center of the cord.
A deep longitudinal groove that extends almost to the center of the cord.
Ventral roots of spinal nerves
The ventral roots are made up of axons from multipolar motor neurons located in the ventral horn of gray mater, as well as axons of preganglionic sympathetic neurons.
The ventral roots are made up of axons from multipolar motor neurons located in the ventral horn of gray mater, as well as axons of preganglionic sympathetic neurons.
The ventral roots are made up of axons from multipolar motor neurons located in the ventral horn of gray mater, as well as axons of preganglionic sympathetic neurons.
Ventral rootlets
Collection of somatic and visceral efferent fibers exiting the spinal cord at the anterolateral sulcus.
Action potential
Electrochemical process initiated by impulses carried from the neuron cell body or dendrites to the axon hillock. The impulse then will continue to travel along the length of the axon.
Anterograde transport
Carries cellular parts from the nerve cell body to the periphery along the axon. The cytoskeletal track used for the transport is made up largely of the protein kinesin.
Astrocyte

Largest neuroglial cells that provide physical and metabolic support to neurons. There are two types of astrocytes: protoplasmic (predominately found in the gray matter) and fibrous (predominately found in the white matter). Also play an important role in maintaining the blood-brain barrier.
Derived from glioblasts that differentiated into astroblasts. Astroblasts will further differentiate into either protoplasmic astrocytes or fibrous astrocytes.
Axoaxonic synapse
Synapse between the axon of one neuron (presynaptic) and axon of another neuron (postsynaptic).
Axodendritic synapse
Synapse between the axon of one neuron (presynaptic) and dendrite of another neuron (postsynaptic).
Axon
Process extending from the neuron cell body, responsible for transmitting impulses away from the cell body usually to other neurons or effector cells.
Process extending from the neuron cell body, responsible for transmitting impulses away from the cell body usually to other neurons or effector cells.
Axon hillock
Connection between the axon and the neuron cell body. Location of action potential initiation.
Axosomatic synapse
Synapse between the axon of one neuron (presynaptic) and the cell body of another neuron (postsynaptic).
Bipolar neuron
Neurons that have a single axon and single dendrite. Bipolar neurons are rare and are most often associated with receptors for the special senses (smell, taste, hearing, sight and equilibrium).
Chemical synapse
Transmission of impulses is done via the release of chemical substances, neurotransmitters from the presynaptic neuron to bind on receptors of postsynaptic neurons or effector cells.
Choroid plexus
Combination of the ependymal cells and associated capillaries. Responsible for producing cerebrospinal fluid.
Dendrite
Process(es) extending from the neuron cell body that transmits impulses from the periphery towards the neuron cell body. Larger diameters compared to axons and are unmyelinated.
Process(es) extending from the neuron cell body that transmits impulses from the periphery towards the neuron cell body. Larger diameters compared to axons and are unmyelinated.
Dendritic tree
Term used to describe the arborization of all dendritic extensions for a single neuron. Greatly increase the receptor surface area of a neuron.
Electrical synapse
Transmission of impulses is done via gap junctions, allowing the spread of electrical current from one cell to the next.
Ependymal cells
Epithelial-type cells lining the ventricular cavities of the central nervous system. Cuboidal to columnar in morphological classification.
Ganglion
General term used to define an aggregation of neuron cell bodies specifically located in the peripheral nervous system.
General term used to define an aggregation of neuron cell bodies specifically located in the peripheral nervous system.
Gap junctions
Form of cell-to-cell communication. Each gap junction consists of two connexons, one per cell. Gap junctions allow molecules and ions to freely move between cells.
Gray Matter

General term used to describe the color seen grossly in the central nervous system. The neural tissue is gray in appearance due to the large aggregation of neuron cell bodies. Also contains dendrites, axons and central neuroglia.

General term used to describe the color seen grossly in the central nervous system. The neural tissue is gray in appearance due to the large aggregation of neuron cell bodies. Also contains dendrites, axons and central neuroglia.
Microglia
Small elongated phagocytic cells, which are considered to be a part of the mononuclear phagocytic system. The microglia precursor cells enter the central nervous system by way of the vascular system.
Multipolar neuron
Neurons that have a single axons and two or more dendrites. Motor neurons and interneurons are the most common examples within the nervous system.
Neurons that have a single axons and two or more dendrites. Motor neurons and interneurons are the most common examples within the nervous system.
Neuroglial cells
Supporting, nonconducting cells located in close proximity to neurons.
Supporting, nonconducting cells located in close proximity to neurons.
Neuron cell body (perikaryon)
Contains the euchromatic nucleus and organelles that maintain the neuron.
Neurotransmitters

Endogenous chemicals that are involved in chemical synapses. Located within synaptic vesicles of neurons, the neurotransmitters are released in response to an action potential across the synaptic cleft to bind to the postsynaptic receptors.
Nissl bodies
Appearance of each stack of rough endoplasmic reticulum within the nucleus of the neuron.
Oligodendrocytes
Neuroglial cells found exclusively in the central nervous system. Responsible for the formation and maintenance of myelin along multiple axons.

Derived from glioblasts that differentiated into oligodendroblasts. Oligodendroblasts will further differentiate into oligodendrocytes. These cells are responsible for myelinating axons within the central nervous system.
Pseudounipolar neuron

Neurons have a single axonal process. One end of the axon extends into the periphery and the other end of the axon extends into the central nervous system. Majority of the pseudounipolar neurons are sensory neurons.

Neurons have a single axonal process. One end of the axon extends into the periphery and the other end of the axon extends into the central nervous system. Majority of the pseudounipolar neurons are sensory neurons.
Retrograde transport
Carries cellular parts away from the periphery and towards the neuron cell body. The cytoskeletal track used for transport is made up largely of the protein dynein.
Satellite cells
Neuroglial cells found in the peripheral nervous system, surrounding nerve cell bodies within ganglia to help support the microenvironment.
Schwann cells

Neuroglial cells found only in the peripheral nervous system. Responsible for supporting both myelinated and unmyelinated nerve cell fibers. Each segment of myelin along peripheral axons is composed of a single schwann cell.

Neuroglial cells found only in the peripheral nervous system. Responsible for supporting both myelinated and unmyelinated nerve cell fibers. Each segment of myelin along peripheral axons is composed of a single schwann cell.
Synapse
Specialized junction between neurons that facilitates the transmission of impulses from one neuron to another neuron, or between axons and effector cells.
Specialized junction between neurons that facilitates the transmission of impulses from one neuron to another neuron, or between axons and effector cells.
White matter

General term used to describe the color seen grossly in the central nervous system. The neural tissue is white in appearance due to the large aggregation of myelinated axons. Also contains unmyelinated axons and neuroglial cells.

General term used to describe the color seen grossly in the central nervous system. The neural tissue is white in appearance due to the large aggregation of myelinated axons. Also contains unmyelinated axons and neuroglial cells.
Alar plate (lamina)
Portion of the developing neural tube located dorsal to the sulcus limitans. Develops into the future dorsal horn of gray matter and is associated with afferent functions.
Arachnoid mater
Middle meningeal layer surrounding the tissue of the central nervous system. Both the arachnoid and pia mater make up the leptomeninges, and both are derived from neural crest cells.

Spinal arachnoid mater is an avascular membrane composed of fibrous and elastic connective tissue that lines the dural sac and dural root sheaths. Pressed against the deep surface of the dura mater due to the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid within the subarachnoid space.
Arachnoid trabeculae
Connective tissue structures found in the adult that connects the pia and arachnoid mater. These represent the origin of the pia and arachnoid mater as a single layer.
Connective tissue structures found in the adult that connects the pia and arachnoid mater. These represent the origin of the pia and arachnoid mater as a single layer.
Astrocytes
Derived from glioblasts that differentiated into astroblasts. Astroblasts will further differentiate into either protoplasmic astrocytes or fibrous astrocytes.
Basal plate (lamina)

Portion of the developing neural tube located ventral to the sulcus limitans. Develops into the future ventral and lateral horns of gray matter and contains predominately primary motor neurons. The basal plates are separated on each side by the floor plate, which forms the future ventral median fissure.
Caudal neuropore
Caudal opening of the neural tube; closes approximately on day 27.
Dura mater

The outer-most layer of meninges surrounding the central nervous system. This is the thickest of the three meningeal layers, and is the only layer to be derived from mesenchymal tissue surrounding the neural tube.

Outer-most meningeal layer composed of fibrous and elastic tissues. The dura mater layer is separated from the vertebrae by the extradural space. The dura mater forms the dural sac within the vertebral canal. The dural sac is pierced laterally by the spinal nerves and continues through the intervertebral foramina as the dural root sheaths.
Ependyma

Ependymal epithelial layer which forms following the formation of neuroblasts and glioblasts from the neuroepithelium. Ependymal cells will line the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
Glioblasts

Primordial supporting cells of the central nervous system, which differentiate from the neuroepithelial cells following cessation of neuroblast formation. These glial cell precursors migrate from the ventricular zone to the marginal zone and mantle zones.
Glioblasts

Primordial supporting cells of the central nervous system, which differentiate from the neuroepithelial cells following cessation of neuroblast formation. These glial cell precursors migrate from the ventricular zone to the marginal zone and mantle zones.
Lateral gray horn

Adult portion of the spinal cord derived from the embryological basal plates. Axons of neurons located within the lateral gray horn grow out of the spinal cord and form a portion the ventral root of spinal nerves.
Leptomeninges
Name given to both the pia and arachnoid mater meningeal layers. The two layers are combined into one name due to both coming from the same origin, neural crest cells.
Mantle zone

Intermediate layer of the developing spinal cord. Neuroblasts that originated in the ventricular zone migrate superficially to occupy this space. Eventually this zone will form the gray matter of the spinal cord.
Marginal zone
Superficial layer of the developing spinal cord. Composed of the outer parts of the neuroepithelial cells. Eventually this zone will form the white matter of the spinal cord.
Meninges

Membrane that covers the neural tube. The meninges form three different layers, the dura, arachnoid and pia mater. The dura mater develops from the overlying mesenchyme, while the arachnoid and pia mater layers develop from neural crest cells.

Membrane that covers the neural tube. The meninges form three different layers, the dura, arachnoid and pia mater. The dura mater develops from the overlying mesenchyme, while the arachnoid and pia mater layers develop from neural crest cells.
Meningomyelocele
Classification of spina bifida cystica, in which the spinal cord/nerve roots and mingeal layers/cerebrospinal fluid protrude through the neural arch defect
Mesenchymal cells
A type of embryonic connective tissue derived from mesoderm. Have the ability to differentiate into various cell types including: osteoblasts, chondroblasts, myocytes and adipocytes.
Microglial cells
Derived from mesenchymal cells within the bone marrow and located throughout the gray and white matter. Microglial cells invade the central nervous system late in the fetal period via blood vessels.
Neural canal
The lumen of the neural tube, which communicates openly with the amniotic cavity. Forms the future central canal of the spinal cord and ventricular system of the brain.
Neural crest

An area of cells that originate from the neural plate and non-neural ectoderm. During neurulation, both sides of the neural plate approach each other and fuse forming the neural tube. The neural crest is separated from the remaining ectoderm to occupy the location between the neural tube and ectoderm.
Neural crest cells

The neural crest tissue separates into neural crest cells following neurulation. Neural crest cells have the ability to differentiate into numerous cells such as: smooth muscle cells, peripheral ganglia, glial cells, melanocytes and the craniofacial cartilage and bone.
Neural folds
Structure that arises from the neural plate (ectoderm) and during neurulation is induced to approach the other neural fold. Fusion of the neural folds forms the neural tube.
Neural groove
A shallow groove that develops within the neural plate between both neural folds. The neural groove upon fusion of the neural tube will form the ventricular system within the central nervous system.
Neural plate
Thickened area of ectoderm formed by both the neural folds and neural groove. Proliferation of the plate is induced by the notochord and underlying paraxial mesoderm.
Neural tube
Precursor to the central nervous system. Formed by fusion of the bilateral neural folds.
Neural tube defects
General term used to describe any congenital anomalies affecting the developing neural tube. Commonly neural tube defects are caused by a failure of closing the neural tube.
Neuroblasts

Primordial neurons, which are the first cells to develop from the neuroepithelial cells within the ventricular zone. These neuron precursors migrate from the ventricular zone to occupy the mantle zone.
Neuroectoderm
Specialized section of ectoderm that receives protein signals to develop into the nervous system. The neuroectoderm will develop into the neural crest cells and the neural tube.
Neurula
The name given to the developing embryo during the stage of neurulation.
Neurulation
Term describing the formation of the neural plate and neural tube. Begins around days 22-23 near the region of somites 4-6.
Notochord

Rod-shaped structure that is derived from mesodermal tissue, and serves as the primitive axis of the developing embryo. Formation of the notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to thicken and form the neural plate. The notochord largely degenerates, but small portions persist as the nucleus pulposus portion of the intervertebral discs.
Pia mater
Deepest meningeal layer surrounding the tissue of the central nervous system. Both the pia and arachnoid mater make up the leptomeninges, and both are derived from neural crest cells.

Innermost meningeal layer, which consists of flattened cells directly following the surface features of the spinal cord. The pia mater surrounds the nerve roots and spinal blood vessels. Distal to the conus medullaris the pia mater continues as the filum terminale.
Rostral neuropore
Cranial opening of the developing neural tube; closes approximately on day 25.
Spina bifida cystica

Neural tube defect in which the neural arches do not grow and fuse together in the midline. This is the more severe case of spina bifida, where protrusion of the spinal cord and nervous tissue (meningomyelocele) and/or meninges (meningocele) may occupy a cyst-like space.
Spina bifida occulta

Neural tube defect in which the neural arches do not grow and fuse together in the midline. This is generally a small space between the neural arches and mostly produces no clinical symptoms. In the minor form, the patient may present with a small dimple and a tuft of hair in the lower back.
Spinal ganglion cells

The pseudounipolar neurons that occupy the dorsal root ganglion. The peripheral processes convey sensory endings from somatic and visceral structures. The central processes occupy the dorsal roots of spinal nerves and enter the spinal cord.
Subarachnoid space

Fluid filled space that develops within the leptomeninges of the developing embryo. This space separates the pia and arachnoid mater in the adult. Cerebrospinal fluid occupies this space around the central nervous system.

Fluid filled space that develops within the leptomeninges of the developing embryo. This space separates the pia and arachnoid mater in the adult. Cerebrospinal fluid occupies this space around the central nervous system.
Sulcus limitans
Shallow groove found bilaterally on the lateral side of the developing spinal cord. The sulcus limitans separates the alar and basal plates.
Ventricular zone
The deepest layer (adjacent to the neural canal) of the developing spinal cord. Consists of neuroepithelial cells, which will give rise to all neurons and macroglial cells of the spinal cord.
Afferent neurons
Neurons responsible for relaying sensory information. Cell bodies are located predominately within the dorsal root ganglion.
Anterior spinal artery
Formed by the union of branches of the vertebral arteries. Responsible for supplying blood to the anterior 1/3 of the spinal cord.
Arachnoid mater

Spinal arachnoid mater is an avascular membrane composed of fibrous and elastic connective tissue that lines the dural sac and dural root sheaths. Pressed against the deep surface of the dura mater due to the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid within the subarachnoid space.
Autonomic nervous system

A functional subdivision of the nervous system that functions largely outside of conscious control and acts to control visceral functions. The two subdivisions within the autonomic nervous system are the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems, which act as antagonistic to each other. Preganglionic cell bodies of the sympathetic nervous system reside within the intermediolateral cell column. Some of the preganglionic cell bodies of the parasympathetic nervous system reside in the sacral parasympathetic nuclei (S2-4).
Central nervous system
A structural subdivision of the nervous system, which consists of the brain and spinal cord.
Cerebrospinal fluid

Clear fluid found surrounding the brain and spinal cord. The fluid is produced within the choroid plexus of the brain. The fluid acts as a cushion and immunological protection for the brain. The cerebrospinal fluid surrounds the brain and spinal cord within the subarachnoid space.
Denticulate ligaments
Sawtooth shaped extensions of pia mater that attach the spinal cord to the dura mater.
Dorsal rami of spinal nerves
Dorsal branch of the spinal nerves that consists of somatic motor and sensory axons as well as visceral motor axons.
Efferent neurons

Neurons responsible for innervation of muscle tissue. Somatic efferent neurons are predominately located within the ventral horn of gray matter. Visceral efferent neurons are located through out the central nervous system.
Endoneurium
Thin connective tissue layer that surrounds individual axons.
Epidural space
Space between the dura mater meningeal layer and the vertebrae. Consists predominately of fat and the internal vertebral venous plexus.
Epineurium
Thick connective tissue surrounding multiple nerve fascicles, forming the outer covering of nerves.
Lateral horn of gray matter
Column of cells primarily involved in the sympathetic nervous system. This grouping of cells is also referred to as the intermediolateral cell column.
Myotome
The muscles fibers that receive innervation from a single spinal nerve.
Nerve plexus
A branching network of interconnecting nerves. There are four major plexuses throughout the body (cervical, brachial, lumbar and sacral). All nerve plexuses are formed by ventral rami.
Neurons
The structural and functional units of the nervous system. These cells are specialized for rapid communication.
Perineurium
Dense connective tissue surrounding individual nerve fascicles.
Peripheral nervous system
A structural subdivision of the nervous system, which consists of the nerves and ganglia located outside of the brain and spinal cord.
Posterior spinal artery
Paired branches of the vertebral or posterior inferior cerebellar arteries. Each is responsible for supplying blood for 1/3 of the spinal cord.
Radicular arteries

Supplemental blood supply to the spinal cord. The anterior and posterior branches run along the ventral and dorsal roots respectively. Radicular arteries are branches off of various segmental arteries such as the ascending cervical, intercostal and lumbar arteries.
Segmental medullary arteries

Branches of the ascending cervical, deep cervical, vertebral, posterior intercostal and lumbar arteries that anastomose with the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. The largest anterior segmental medullary artery is the artery of Adamkiewicz, which typically branches off the left posterior intercostal artery.
Spinal dural sac
The continuation of the dura mater below the ending of the spinal cord (L1-2). The dural sac surrounds the lumbar cistern, cauda equina and the filum terminale.
Somatic nervous system

A functional subdivision of the nervous system that functions largely within conscious control. The somatic nervous system predominately innervates skeletal muscle (efferent) and provides innervation to the skin (afferent).
Ventral rami of spinal nerves

Ventral branch of the spinal nerves that consists of somatic motor and sensory axons as well as visceral motor and sensory axons. Ventral rami at various levels of the spinal cord will combine to form the various plexuses of the body.
